metadata.case_name: State of Kerala v. Respondent Company

facts.text: The respondent sold trees of spontaneous growth in its estate for Rs. 50,000 during the assessment year 1963-64.
The assessing authority levied sales tax by treating the aforesaid amount as taxable turnover under the Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963.
In appeal, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the order of the assessing authority.

The Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal held that the respondent company was not a dealer within the meaning of s. 2(viii) of the Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963, as the trees sold were of spontaneous growth, uprooting was not done by the respondent, and no process was employed by which it could be said that timber had been produced by it.
The appellant filed a revision petition before the Kerala High Court against the Tribunal's order.
The Kerala High Court dismissed the revision petition in limine on September 15, 1966.
The appellant filed an appeal by special leave to the Supreme Court.
The respondent did not appear before the Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, a person owning and maintaining private forest and selling trees of spontaneous growth therein, is a dealer within the meaning of section 2(viii) of the Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963?
Whether such a person is liable to the levy of sales-tax in respect of sales of his timber, under the said Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: The Appellate Tribunal erred in assuming that any agricultural, horticultural or other process was involved in producing the timber sold.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 2(viii) of the Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963

petitioner_arguments.text: Maintenance of a private forest with a view to producing and selling valuable timber, with the usual attributes of business (periodicity, continuity and profit motive), amounts to such process and falls within 'agriculture, horticulture or otherwise', particularly when the respondent owns substantial area of forest land and sells timber from spontaneous growth year after year for profit.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 2(viii) of the Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963

court_reasoning.text: The sole question is whether on the findings given by the Appellate Tribunal the respondent can be regarded as a dealer within the definition given in s. 2(viii).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dealer means any person who carries on the business of buying, selling etc. and includes a person who sells goods produced by him by manufacture, agriculture, horticulture or otherwise.

court_reasoning.text: Trees which have grown spontaneously and without any plantation by that person cannot be regarded as having been produced by him by agriculture or horticulture. The word 'otherwise' also cannot cover trees of spontaneous growth since the element of production must be present.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Produced' means to bring forth, bring into being or existence from its raw materials or elements; involves volition and effort employing some process.

court_reasoning.text: The juxtaposition of 'manufacture' with 'agriculture' and 'horticulture' is significant. The respondent has not been found to have done anything towards the production of the trees and even the cutting has been done by the contractor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondent cannot be regarded as a person who sells goods produced by him by agriculture, horticulture or otherwise.

holdings.text: The respondent cannot possibly be regarded as a person who sells goods produced by him by agriculture, horticulture or otherwise, and thus is not a dealer under s. 2(viii) of the Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963.
The respondent is not liable to sales tax on sales of trees of spontaneous growth.

statutes_cited.name: Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963 (Act 15 of 1963)
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of 'dealer' interpreted to exclude seller of spontaneously grown trees not produced by manufacture, agriculture, horticulture or otherwise

outcome.summary: The appeal fails and is dismissed as the respondent is not a dealer under s. 2(viii) of the Act. No order as to costs in this Court since respondent did not appear.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; upholds Tribunal and High Court orders in favor of respondent

key_quotes.text: Such trees which have grown spontaneously and without any plantation by that person cannot possibly be regarded as having been produced by him by agriculture or horticulture.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on why respondent not a 'dealer'

key_quotes.text: The intention in employing the word produced obviously was to introduce an element of volition and effort involving the employment of some process for bringing into existence the goods.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets 'produced' in s. 2(viii) requiring active production
